an3.65:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena kesamuttaṃ nāma kālāmānaṃ nigamo tadavasari.
an3.65:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kālāmas named Kesamutta.

an3.65:1.4.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kesamuttaṃ anuppatto.
an3.65:1.4.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Kesamutta.

an3.65:1.5.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

an3.65:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …’

an3.65:1.7.pli: sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’”ti.
an3.65:1.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

an3.65:2.1.pli: Atha kho kesamuttiyā kālāmā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te kesamuttiyā kālāmā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an3.65:2.1.eng: Then the Kālāmas went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side the Kālāmas said to the Buddha:

an3.65:3.1.eng: “There are, sir, some ascetics and brahmins who come to Kesamutta.

an3.65:3.2.pli: Te sakaṃyeva vādaṃ dīpenti jotenti, parappavādaṃ pana khuṃsenti vambhenti paribhavanti omakkhiṃ karonti.
an3.65:3.2.eng: They explain and promote only their own doctrine, while they attack, badmouth, disparage, and smear the doctrines of others.

an3.65:3.3.pli: Aparepi, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kesamuttaṃ āgacchanti.
an3.65:3.3.eng: Then some other ascetics and brahmins come to Kesamutta.

an3.65:3.4.pli: Tepi sakaṃyeva vādaṃ dīpenti jotenti, parappavādaṃ pana khuṃsenti vambhenti paribhavanti omakkhiṃ karonti.
an3.65:3.4.eng: They too explain and promote only their own doctrine, while they attack, badmouth, disparage, and smear the doctrines of others.

an3.65:3.5.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, amhākaṃ hoteva kaṅkhā hoti vicikicchā:
an3.65:3.5.eng: So, sir, we’re doubting and uncertain:

an3.65:3.6.pli: ‘ko su nāma imesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ āha, ko musā’”ti?
an3.65:3.6.eng: ‘I wonder who of these respected ascetics and brahmins speaks the truth, and who speaks falsehood?’”

an3.65:3.7.eng: “It is enough, Kālāmas, for you to be doubting and uncertain.

an3.65:3.8.pli: Kaṅkhanīyeva pana vo ṭhāne vicikicchā uppannā.
an3.65:3.8.eng: Doubt has come up in you about an uncertain matter.

an3.65:4.1.pli: Etha tumhe, kālāmā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.65:4.1.eng: Please, Kālāmas, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’

an3.65:4.2.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.65:4.3.pli: ‘ime dhammā akusalā, ime dhammā sāvajjā, ime dhammā viññugarahitā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattantī’ti, atha tumhe, kālāmā, pajaheyyātha.
an3.65:4.3.eng: ‘These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering’, then you should give them up.

an3.65:5.2.pli: lobho purisassa ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati hitāya vā ahitāya vā”ti?
an3.65:5.2.eng: Does greed come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”

an3.65:7.1.pli: “Luddho panāyaṃ, kālāmā, purisapuggalo lobhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.65:7.1.eng: “A greedy individual, overcome by greed, kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.65:9.2.pli: doso purisassa ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati hitāya vā ahitāya vā”ti?
an3.65:9.2.eng: Does hate come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”

an3.65:11.1.pli: “Duṭṭho panāyaṃ, kālāmā, purisapuggalo dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.65:11.1.eng: “A hateful individual, overcome by hate, kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.65:13.2.pli: moho purisassa ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati hitāya vā ahitāya vā”ti?
an3.65:13.2.eng: Does delusion come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”

an3.65:15.1.pli: “Mūḷho panāyaṃ, kālāmā, purisapuggalo mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.65:15.1.eng: “A deluded individual, overcome by delusion, kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.65:17.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, kālāmā, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vā”ti?
an3.65:17.1.eng: “What do you think, Kālāmas, are these things skillful or unskillful?”

an3.65:23.1.pli: “Samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti, no vā?
an3.65:23.1.eng: “When you undertake them, do they lead to harm and suffering, or not?

an3.65:23.2.eng: Or how do you see this?”

an3.65:24.1.eng: “When you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering.

an3.65:25.3.pli: Mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.65:25.3.eng: don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think “The ascetic is our respected teacher.”

an3.65:25.4.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.65:25.5.pli: “ime dhammā akusalā, ime dhammā sāvajjā, ime dhammā viññugarahitā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattantīti, atha tumhe, kālāmā, pajaheyyāthā”’ti,
an3.65:25.5.eng: “These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering”, then you should give them up.’

an3.65:25.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.65:25.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.65:26.1.pli: Etha tumhe, kālāmā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.65:26.1.eng: Please, Kālāmas, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’

an3.65:26.2.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.65:26.3.pli: ‘ime dhammā kusalā, ime dhammā anavajjā, ime dhammā viññuppasatthā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantī’ti, atha tumhe, kālāmā, upasampajja vihareyyātha.
an3.65:26.3.eng: ‘These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness’, then you should acquire them and keep them.

an3.65:27.2.pli: alobho purisassa ajjhattaṃ uppajjamāno uppajjati hitāya vā ahitāya vā”ti?
an3.65:27.2.eng: Does contentment come up in a person for their welfare or harm?”

an3.65:29.1.pli: “Aluddho panāyaṃ, kālāmā, purisapuggalo lobhena anabhibhūto apariyādinnacitto neva pāṇaṃ hanati, na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na paradāraṃ gacchati, na musā bhaṇati, na parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.65:29.1.eng: “An individual who is content, not overcome by greed, doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

an3.65:31.2.eng: Does love come up in a person for their welfare or harm? …

an3.65:31.3.eng: Does understanding come up in a person for their welfare or harm? …

an3.65:31.4.eng: Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

an3.65:33.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, kālāmā, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vā”ti?
an3.65:33.1.eng: “What do you think, Kālāmas, are these things skillful or unskillful?”

an3.65:39.1.pli: “Samattā samādinnā hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti no vā?
an3.65:39.1.eng: “When you undertake them, do they lead to welfare and happiness, or not?

an3.65:39.2.eng: Or how do you see this?”

an3.65:40.1.eng: “When you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness.

an3.65:41.3.pli: Mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.65:41.3.eng: don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think “The ascetic is our respected teacher.”

an3.65:41.4.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.65:41.5.pli: ime dhammā kusalā, ime dhammā anavajjā, ime dhammā viññuppasatthā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantīti, atha tumhe, kālāmā, upasampajja vihareyyāthā’ti,
an3.65:41.5.eng: “These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness”, then you should acquire them and keep them.’

an3.65:41.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.65:41.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.65:42.1.pli: Sa kho so, kālāmā, ariyasāvako evaṃ vigatābhijjho vigatabyāpādo asammūḷho sampajāno patissato mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ, iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjhena pharitvā viharati.
an3.65:42.1.eng: Then that noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an3.65:42.2.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an3.65:42.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of rejoicing to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an3.65:42.4.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ, iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjhena pharitvā viharati.
an3.65:42.4.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an3.65:43.1.pli: Sa kho so, kālāmā, ariyasāvako evaṃ averacitto evaṃ abyāpajjhacitto evaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhacitto evaṃ visuddhacitto.
an3.65:43.1.eng: When that noble disciple has a mind that’s free of enmity and ill will, uncorrupted and purified,

an3.65:43.2.pli: Tassa diṭṭheva dhamme cattāro assāsā adhigatā honti.
an3.65:43.2.eng: they’ve won four consolations in this very life.

an3.65:43.3.pli: ‘Sace kho pana atthi paro loko, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, athāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissāmī’ti, ayamassa paṭhamo assāso adhigato hoti.
an3.65:43.3.eng: ‘If it turns out there is another world, and good and bad deeds have a result, then—when the body breaks up, after death—I’ll be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ This is the first consolation they’ve won.

an3.65:44.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana natthi paro loko, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, athāhaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme averaṃ abyāpajjhaṃ anīghaṃ sukhiṃ attānaṃ pariharāmī’ti, ayamassa dutiyo assāso adhigato hoti.
an3.65:44.1.eng: ‘If it turns out there is no other world, and good and bad deeds don’t have a result, then in this very life I’ll keep myself free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy.’ This is the second consolation they’ve won.

an3.65:45.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana karoto karīyati pāpaṃ, na kho panāhaṃ kassaci pāpaṃ cetemi.
an3.65:45.1.eng: ‘If it turns out that bad things happen to people who do bad things, then since I have no bad intentions,

an3.65:45.2.pli: Akarontaṃ kho pana maṃ pāpakammaṃ kuto dukkhaṃ phusissatī’ti, ayamassa tatiyo assāso adhigato hoti.
an3.65:45.2.eng: and since I’m not doing anything bad, how can suffering touch me?’ This is the third consolation they’ve won.

an3.65:46.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, athāhaṃ ubhayeneva visuddhaṃ attānaṃ samanupassāmī’ti, ayamassa catuttho assāso adhigato hoti.
an3.65:46.1.eng: ‘If it turns out that bad things don’t happen to people who do bad things, then I still see myself pure on both sides.’ This is the fourth consolation they’ve won.

an3.65:47.1.pli: Sa kho so, kālāmā, ariyasāvako evaṃ averacitto evaṃ abyāpajjhacitto evaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhacitto evaṃ visuddhacitto.
an3.65:47.1.eng: When that noble disciple has a mind that’s free of enmity and ill will, undefiled and purified,

an3.65:47.2.pli: Tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime cattāro assāsā adhigatā hontī”ti.
an3.65:47.2.eng: they’ve won these four consolations in this very life.”

an3.65:48.1.eng: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

an3.65:48.2.pli: Sa kho so, bhante, ariyasāvako evaṃ averacitto evaṃ abyāpajjhacitto evaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhacitto evaṃ visuddhacitto.
an3.65:48.2.eng: When that noble disciple has a mind that’s free of enmity and ill will, undefiled and purified,

an3.65:48.3.pli: Tassa diṭṭheva dhamme cattāro assāsā adhigatā honti.
an3.65:48.3.eng: they’ve won these four consolations in this very life. …

an3.65:48.4.pli: ‘Sace kho pana atthi paro loko, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, athāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissāmī’ti, ayamassa paṭhamo assāso adhigato hoti.

an3.65:49.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana natthi paro loko, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, athāhaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme averaṃ abyāpajjhaṃ anīghaṃ sukhiṃ attānaṃ pariharāmī’ti, ayamassa dutiyo assāso adhigato hoti.

an3.65:50.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana karoto karīyati pāpaṃ, na kho panāhaṃ kassaci pāpaṃ cetemi, akarontaṃ kho pana maṃ pāpakammaṃ kuto dukkhaṃ phusissatī’ti, ayamassa tatiyo assāso adhigato hoti.

an3.65:51.1.pli: ‘Sace kho pana karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, athāhaṃ ubhayeneva visuddhaṃ attānaṃ samanupassāmī’ti, ayamassa catuttho assāso adhigato hoti.

an3.65:52.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhante, ariyasāvako evaṃ averacitto evaṃ abyāpajjhacitto evaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhacitto evaṃ visuddhacitto.

an3.65:52.2.pli: Tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime cattāro assāsā adhigatā honti.

an3.65:53.2.pli: ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
an3.65:53.2.eng: We go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

an3.65:53.3.pli: Upāsake no, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
an3.65:53.3.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

an3.66:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā nandako sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
an3.66:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Nandaka was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

an3.66:1.3.pli: Atha kho sāḷho ca migāranattā sāṇo ca sekhuniyanattā yenāyasmā nandako tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nandakaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho sāḷhaṃ migāranattāraṃ āyasmā nandako etadavoca:
an3.66:1.3.eng: Then Sāḷha, Migāra’s grandson, and Rohaṇa, Pekhuṇiya’s grandson went up to Venerable Nandaka, bowed, and sat down to one side. Then Venerable Nandaka said to Sāḷha:

an3.66:2.1.pli: “Etha tumhe, sāḷhā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.66:2.1.eng: “Please, Sāḷha and friend, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’

an3.66:2.2.pli: Yadā tumhe, sāḷhā, attanāva jāneyyātha ‘ime dhammā akusalā, ime dhammā sāvajjā, ime dhammā viññugarahitā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattantī’ti, atha tumhe, sāḷhā, pajaheyyātha.
an3.66:2.2.eng: But when you know for yourselves: ‘These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering’, then you should give them up.

an3.66:5.1.eng: “‘Covetousness’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:5.2.pli: Luddho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, abhijjhālu pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.66:5.2.eng: A person who is greedy and covetous kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.66:9.1.eng: “‘Malice’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:9.2.pli: Duṭṭho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, byāpannacitto pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.66:9.2.eng: A hateful and malicious person kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.66:13.1.eng: “‘Ignorance’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:13.2.pli: Mūḷho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, avijjāgato pāṇampi hanati, adinnampi ādiyati, paradārampi gacchati, musāpi bhaṇati, parampi tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
an3.66:13.2.eng: A person who is deluded and ignorant kills living creatures, steals, commits adultery, lies, and encourages others to do the same. Is that for their lasting harm and suffering?”

an3.66:15.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, sāḷhā, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vā”ti?
an3.66:15.1.eng: “What do you think, Sāḷha, are these things skillful or unskillful?”

an3.66:21.1.pli: “Samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti, no vā?
an3.66:21.1.eng: “When you undertake them, do they lead to harm and suffering, or not?

an3.66:21.2.eng: Or how do you see this?”

an3.66:22.1.eng: “When you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering.

an3.66:23.1.eng: “So, Sāḷha and friend, when I said:

an3.66:23.2.pli: ‘etha tumhe, sāḷhā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.66:23.2.eng: ‘Please, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think “The ascetic is our respected teacher.”

an3.66:23.3.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.66:23.4.pli: ime dhammā akusalā, ime dhammā sāvajjā, ime dhammā viññugarahitā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattantīti, atha tumhe, sāḷhā, pajaheyyāthā’ti,
an3.66:23.4.eng: “These things are unskillful, blameworthy, criticized by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to harm and suffering”, then you should give them up.’

an3.66:23.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.66:23.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.66:24.1.pli: Etha tumhe, sāḷhā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.66:24.1.eng: Please, Sāḷha and friend, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think ‘The ascetic is our respected teacher.’

an3.66:24.2.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.66:24.3.pli: ‘ime dhammā kusalā, ime dhammā anavajjā, ime dhammā viññuppasatthā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantī’ti, atha tumhe, sāḷhā, upasampajja vihareyyātha.
an3.66:24.3.eng: ‘These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness’, then you should acquire them and keep them.

an3.66:25.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, sāḷhā, atthi alobho”ti?
an3.66:25.1.eng: What do you think? Is contentment real?”

an3.66:27.1.eng: “‘Satisfaction’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:27.2.pli: Aluddho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, anabhijjhālu neva pāṇaṃ hanati, na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na paradāraṃ gacchati, na musā bhaṇati, parampi na tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.66:27.2.eng: A person who is content and satisfied doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

an3.66:29.1.eng: What do you think? Is love real?”

an3.66:31.1.eng: “‘Kindness’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:31.2.pli: Aduṭṭho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, abyāpannacitto neva pāṇaṃ hanati, na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na paradāraṃ gacchati, na musā bhaṇati, parampi na tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.66:31.2.eng: A loving and kind-hearted person doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

an3.66:35.1.eng: “‘Knowledge’ is what I mean by this.

an3.66:35.2.pli: Amūḷho kho ayaṃ, sāḷhā, vijjāgato neva pāṇaṃ hanati, na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na paradāraṃ gacchati, na musā bhaṇati, parampi na tathattāya samādapeti, yaṃ sa hoti dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.66:35.2.eng: A person who understands and knows doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit adultery, lie, or encourage others to do the same. Is that for their lasting welfare and happiness?”

an3.66:37.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, sāḷhā, ime dhammā kusalā vā akusalā vā”ti?
an3.66:37.1.eng: “What do you think, Sāḷha, are these things skillful or unskillful?”

an3.66:43.1.pli: “Samattā samādinnā hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti, no vā?
an3.66:43.1.eng: “When you undertake them, do they lead to welfare and happiness, or not?

an3.66:43.2.eng: Or how do you see this?”

an3.66:44.1.eng: “When you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness.

an3.66:45.1.eng: “So, Sāḷha and friend, when I said:

an3.66:45.2.pli: ‘etha tumhe, sāḷhā, mā anussavena, mā paramparāya, mā itikirāya, mā piṭakasampadānena, mā takkahetu, mā nayahetu, mā ākāraparivitakkena, mā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā, mā bhabbarūpatāya, mā samaṇo no garūti.
an3.66:45.2.eng: ‘Please, don’t go by oral transmission, don’t go by lineage, don’t go by testament, don’t go by canonical authority, don’t rely on logic, don’t rely on inference, don’t go by reasoned train of thought, don’t go by the acceptance of a view after deliberation, don’t go by the appearance of competence, and don’t think “The ascetic is our respected teacher.”

an3.66:45.3.eng: But when you know for yourselves:

an3.66:45.4.pli: ime dhammā kusalā, ime dhammā anavajjā, ime dhammā viññuppasatthā, ime dhammā samattā samādinnā dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantīti, atha tumhe, sāḷhā, upasampajja vihareyyāthā’ti,
an3.66:45.4.eng: “These things are skillful, blameless, praised by sensible people, and when you undertake them, they lead to welfare and happiness”, then you should acquire them and keep them.’

an3.66:45.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.66:45.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.66:46.1.pli: Sa kho so, sāḷhā, ariyasāvako evaṃ vigatābhijjho vigatabyāpādo asammūḷho sampajāno patissato mettāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
an3.66:46.1.eng: Then that noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of love …

an3.66:46.4.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ, iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjhena pharitvā viharati.
an3.66:46.4.eng: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an3.66:46.6.pli: ‘atthi idaṃ, atthi hīnaṃ, atthi paṇītaṃ, atthi imassa saññāgatassa uttari nissaraṇan’ti.
an3.66:46.6.eng: ‘There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond the scope of perception.’

an3.66:46.7.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati;
an3.66:46.7.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an3.66:46.8.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

an3.66:46.9.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
an3.66:46.9.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

an3.66:47.2.pli: ‘ahu pubbe lobho, tadahu akusalaṃ, so etarahi natthi, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ;
an3.66:47.2.eng: ‘Formerly there was greed, which was unskillful. Now there is none, so that’s skillful.

an3.66:47.3.eng: Formerly there was hate, which was unskillful. Now there is none, so that’s skillful.

an3.66:47.4.pli: ahu pubbe moho, tadahu akusalaṃ, so etarahi natthi, iccetaṃ kusalan’ti.
an3.66:47.4.eng: Formerly there was delusion, which was unskillful. Now there is none, so that’s skillful.’

an3.66:47.5.pli: So diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītibhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
an3.66:47.5.eng: So they live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
